articles.headline: McCain Vows to End ‘Partisan Rancor’
articles.snippet: Senator John McCain sought to move from a convention marked by an effort to reassure the party base to an appeal to a broader electorate.
articles.abstract: Senator John McCain sought to move from a convention marked by an effort to reassure the party base to an appeal to a broader electorate.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL — Senator John McCain accepted the Republican presidential nomination Thursday with a pledge to move the nation beyond “partisan rancor” and narrow self-interest in a speech in which he markedly toned down the blistering attacks on Senator Barack Obama that had filled the first nights of his convention.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Michael Cooper

articles.headline: Defaults Could Net Bigger Fish
articles.snippet: Loan defaults are rising, but the victims seem to be small companies in industries with big problems.
articles.abstract: Loan defaults are rising, but the victims seem to be small companies in industries with big problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: The weak go first, and people take comfort from the very weakness of the fallen. The fact it is only the weak who are suffering is taken as proof that there is no general problem.

articles.headline: As Oil Prices Fall, OPEC Faces a Balancing Act
articles.snippet: For oil producers that have grown accustomed to rising revenues, falling oil prices are turning into a cause for concern, if not quite panic.
articles.abstract: For oil producers that have grown accustomed to rising revenues, falling oil prices are turning into a cause for concern, if not quite panic.
articles.lead_paragraph: The decline in oil prices has been a welcome relief for consumers and a rare piece of positive news in a bleak economic landscape. But for oil producers that have grown accustomed to rising revenue, falling prices are turning into a cause for concern, if not quite panic.

articles.headline: Wasilla: A Lot Like New York, Only Smaller
articles.snippet: Throughout this long national campaign, people who focus on the future of American cities have been dying to hear their issues discussed. Could Sarah Palin be their last great hope?
articles.abstract: Throughout this long national campaign, people who focus on the future of American cities have been dying to hear their issues discussed. Could Sarah Palin be their last great hope?
articles.lead_paragraph: Throughout this long national campaign, people who focus on the future of American cities have been dying to hear their issues discussed, from roads and mass transit to housing and homelessness. It’s not as if these are abstract matters, not with 80 percent of the population living in cities and their suburbs. Thus far, those people have been disappointed. They’ve heard next to nothing.

articles.headline: Main Bank of China Is in Need of Capital
articles.snippet: China’s central bank is in a bind, after snapping up roughly $1 trillion worth of Treasury bonds and mortgage-backed debt issued by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac over the last seven years.
articles.abstract: China’s central bank is in a bind, after snapping up roughly $1 trillion worth of Treasury bonds and mortgage-backed debt issued by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac over the last seven years.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China’s central bank is in a bind.

articles.headline: Lehman Weighs Split to Shed Troubling Loans
articles.snippet: The ailing Wall Street bank is working toward a radical solution in its fight for survival: Splitting itself into a “good” bank and a “bad” one.
articles.abstract: The ailing Wall Street bank is working toward a radical solution in its fight for survival: Splitting itself into a “good” bank and a “bad” one.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lehman Brothers, the ailing Wall Street bank, is working toward a radical solution in its fight for survival: Splitting itself into a “good” bank and a “bad” one.
articles.byline: By Ben White and Jenny Anderson

articles.headline: Bhutto Widower With Clouded Past Is Set to Lead
articles.snippet: Asif Ali Zardari will start his tenure as Pakistan’s president burdened by unproven corruption allegations.
articles.abstract: Asif Ali Zardari will start his tenure as Pakistan’s president burdened by unproven corruption allegations.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Asif Ali Zardari, the widower of Benazir Bhutto, is set to become president on Saturday, an accidental ascent for a man known more as a wheeler-dealer than a leader. He will start his tenure burdened by a history of corruption allegations that cloud his reputation even as they remain unproved.

articles.headline: Altria Said to Be in Talks With Tobacco Maker UST
articles.snippet: Altria Group is in advanced talks to buy UST, the maker of the popular Skoal and Copenhagen smokeless tobacco brands, for more than $10 billion. The terms could not be learned.
articles.abstract: Altria Group is in advanced talks to buy UST, the maker of the popular Skoal and Copenhagen smokeless tobacco brands, for more than $10 billion. The terms could not be learned.
articles.lead_paragraph: Altria Group is in advanced talks to buy UST, the maker of the popular Skoal and Copenhagen smokeless tobacco brands, for more than $10 billion, people with close knowledge of the negotiations said late Thursday. The terms could not be learned.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Andrew Martin

articles.headline: Party in Power, Running as if It Weren’t
articles.snippet: Partly by his nature and partly by calculation, John McCain is sounding a call to topple the establishment.
articles.abstract: Partly by his nature and partly by calculation, John McCain is sounding a call to topple the establishment.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL  The nominee’s friend described him as a “restless reformer who will clean up Washington.” His defeated rival described him going to the capital to “drain that swamp.” His running mate described their mission as “change, the goal we share.” And that was at the incumbent party’s convention.

articles.headline: At ESPN, Play-by-Play Goes Virtual
articles.snippet: ESPN is debuting new technology with Electronic Arts that would allow sports commentators to interact with three-dimensional virtual players.
articles.abstract: ESPN is debuting new technology with Electronic Arts that would allow sports commentators to interact with three-dimensional virtual players.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — ESPN, the cable powerhouse that calls itself “Worldwide Leader in Sports,” is looking to extend its domain in virtual worlds by merging video game graphics with real-life sports anchors.

articles.headline: U.S. Jobless Rate Rises Past 6%, Highest Since ’03
articles.snippet: The McCain and Obama campaigns responded quickly to a report that the jobless rate jumped to 6.1 percent in August.
articles.abstract: The McCain and Obama campaigns responded quickly to a report that the jobless rate jumped to 6.1 percent in August.
articles.lead_paragraph: The unemployment rate jumped to 6.1 percent in August, its highest level in five years, pushing the troubles of American workers to the center of the political debate as the presidential campaign enters its final weeks.

articles.headline: Machinists Union at Boeing Says It Will Strike
articles.snippet: The strike, set to begin early Saturday, could potentially delay an important new aircraft, the Dreamliner.
articles.abstract: The strike, set to begin early Saturday, could potentially delay an important new aircraft, the Dreamliner.
articles.lead_paragraph: The union that represents machinists at the Boeing Company said on Friday that it would go on strike early Saturday, potentially delaying the production of an important new aircraft, the Dreamliner.
